segment.tokens: However we determined to give our young urchins a chance
we hoped
the mother hedgehog would be favorably disposed towards her offspring
so we now left her undisturbed
Willy wished to know "
whether hedgehogs were injurious
for " you know "
papa " he said
that country lads gamekeepers always kill them
whenever they have a chance
I am convinced that hedgehogs much more good than harm by the destruction they cause to insects , slugs , snails , field-mice , and other pests of the farm
do
they cause to insects , slugs , snails , field-mice , and other pests of the farm
There is a foolish idea in the minds of the uneducated that these animals suck cows
that these animals suck cows
You have only to laugh at such an absurdity
I doubt
you will scarcely ever succeed persuading such people the idea utterly unsupported by fact
that the idea is a ridiculous utterly unsupported by fact
Hedgehogs will undoubtedly destroy eggs
one can understand
why gamekeepers wage war against them
fearing for the safety of the eggs or young birds of their favorite partridges or pheasants
This is
I suspect however
that hedgehogs seldom molest the nests
do
that the injury they in this respect is very
" But you know "
papa " said Jack
that they will eat young birds
Do you not remember the dead sparrow "
we once gave to a hedgehog
how furiously he went at it
how soon he ate it all up except the feathers
" Yes " added Willy "
and do
you not also remember our putting a toad in the same box with a hedgehog
Oh
how angry he seemed
how savagely he shook the unfortunate toad
He did not however seem to like the flavour soon "
gave up the fight
Hedgehogs will certainly destroy young birds
but we must remember to set the good against the harm
any animal does
we strike the balance
as I said
I suspect in this case
the good will largely preponderate
Hedgehogs are extremely of beetles
they seize on them with great earnestness
they crack them with as much delight as you lads crack nuts
as you lads crack nuts
Hedgehogs are sometimes kept in houses for the purpose of eating the cockroaches so often abounding in kitchens
so often abounding
Snakes are also devoured hedgehogs
having occasion to suspect
that hedgehogs sometimes preyed on snakes
The late Professor Buckland " procured a common snake also a hedgehog
The late Professor Buckland put them in a box together
Whether or not the latter recognised its enemy was not
it did not dart from the hedgehog
it kept
creeping gently round the box
The hedgehog was rolled up
The hedgehog did not appear to see the snake
The professor then laid the hedgehog on the snake with that part of the ball where the head and tail meet downwards , and touching it
where the head tail meet downwards
touching it
The snake proceeded to crawl
the hedgehog started
the hedgehog opened slightly
the hedgehog seeing
what was
it gave the snake a hard bite
the hedgehog instantly rolled itself up again
It soon opened a second again a third time
repeating the bite
This done
the hedgehog stood by the snake 's side

the hedgehog passed the whole body of the snake successively through its jaws cracking it breaking the bones at intervals of half an inch or more , by which operation the snake was rendered motionless
intervals of half an inch or more operation the snake was rendered motionless
The hedgehog then placed itself at the tip of the snake 's tail slowly
The hedgehog began to eat upwards
as one would eat a radish without intermission slowly
till half of the snake was devoured
The following morning the remaining half was also completely eaten up "
When rather young these animals make very interesting pets
they soon become tame
they will allow you to stroke their cheeks
You remember our placing a hedgehog on the study table seeing
how it got off on to the ground
It came to the edge the elastic nature of its prickly covering
It threw itself off
It coiling up its body
partly as it fell
enabling it to bear the shock of the fall without the slightest inconvenience
Let
us go on the moors again
watch the coots water-hens in the reedy pools near the aqueduct
Do you see that great tit on a branch of this poplar
He is
actually at work doing a bit of butchery on a small warbler
See
how he is beating the poor little fellow on the head
he wants to get at his brains
" Are there not birds called butcher-birds "
asked Willy "
that fix their victims on thorns
that then peck off their flesh
Shall "
we see any of them
There are three kinds of butcher-birds
three kinds of butcher-birds have been known to come to this country
Two kinds are very
we are not to meet with any of them in our walks
I may as well however tell you something about them
as I have no personal knowledge of the habits of any of the species
I must get my information from other sources
The great grey shrike the red-backed shrike the woodchat shrike are the three of the family
occurring in Great Britain
the red-backed shrike is the only tolerably common arriving in this country late in April quitting it in September
Mr. John Shaw tells me this bird every spring
visits the quarry grounds at Shrewsbury
if he goes there
an early riser can see these birds readily
Mr. Yarrell says
that the great grey shrike is only an occasional to this country
the great grey shrike is generally obtained between autumn and spring
Its food consists of mice , shrews , small birds , frogs , lizards , and large insects
having killed its prey
" it fixes the body in a forked branch upon a sharp thorn the more readily to pull off small pieces from it "
The following remarks are by a gentleman who had one of these birds in confinement "
a gentleman had one of these birds in confinement
" he says "
taken near Norwich in October , 1835 ,
An old bird of this species , " he says , " taken near Norwich in October , 1835 , lived in my possession twelve months
It became very tame
It would readily take its food from my hands
When a bird was given it
it invariably broke the skull
it generally ate the head first
It sometimes held the bird in its claws
It pulled it to pieces in the manner of hawks
It seemed to prefer
forcing part of it through the wires then pulling at it
It always hung
what it could not eat up on the sides of the cage
It would often eat three small birds in a day
In the spring it was very one of its notes a little "
resembling the cry of the kestrel
It is a a bold bird
It is said
that imitating the notes of some of the smaller birds it calls them near it
it then pounces upon some deluded victim
The shrike is used falconers abroad trapping falcons " "
it is fastened to the ground screaming loudly of the approach of a hawk
gives notice to the falconer , who is concealed ,
the falconer is concealed
You will notice in any picture of a shrike how admirably adapted is its curved beak for butchering purposes
how admirably adapted is its curved for butchering purposes
The red-backed shrike " frequents the sides of woods and high hedgerows generally in pairs
The red-backed shrike may frequently be seen
perched on the uppermost branch of an isolated bush on the look out for prey
isolated
The males occasionally make a chirping noise not unlike the note of the sparrow "
It also imitates the voice of small birds
Mr. Yarrell says particularly
" the food of the red-backed shrike is probably shrews small birds various insects particularly the common May-chaffer
Its inclination to attack its power to destroy little birds has been doubted "
it has been seen to kill a bird as large as a finch
it is not unfrequently caught in the clap-nets of London bird-catchers , having struck at their decoy-birds ; "
having struck at their decoy-birds
Mr. Hewitson says " Seeing
I found approaching it a small bird
which it had been operating
a red-backed shrike busy in a hedge firmly fixed upon a blunt thorn
its head was torn off
the body entirely plucked
